description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6QdPPYxpIVh
Fuel gauge model, accessories for fuel stations. Sonda(1) is a closed model.

I was bored on a Saturday afternoon and with an engineer friend. We decided to have a contest to see who could design and build the best printable bow and arrow, using the following constraints: One 100mm x 100mm panel of parts
No more than 2 rubber bands
No adhesive
"Reasonable" print time (under 1.5 hours)
"Reasonable" design time (under 1.5 hours) This was the my entry. The picture is of the first revision, which had a few issues (pins were too small to print cleanly, holes were not oversized enough, pins would shear). The uploaded file is the second revision, which has not yet been tested but should address all of these issues (my printer is down today with "null version reported" so I'll try to get it tested ASAP).

Print the plate, clean the parts up (the holes in particular).
Slide the two leafs over the center piece and put the retainer plate on the back.
Heat up a knife blade (I used a lighter) and press down on the tabs to "fuse" them in place.
Take a piece of hot filament and slide it into the hole on the center piece of the bow; this is now your guide.
Slip your end cap over the filament and mushroom the tip again with a hot knife to keep you from loosing the cap when launching pencils.
Finally, take a rubber band (you'll need a fairly long one) and stretch it across the nubs at the ends of the leaves.
Load a pencil, draw back, and fire!

comments.text: With the right firmware (Sprinter/Marlin) that supports acceleration, you can run much higher. I'm printing at 70mm/s atm, and with a layer height of 0.4mm Skeinforge says this print would take around 30 Minutes each (so i'd guess it's more like 40-45 minutes). Since we are talking Mendel, we could print up to four at a time with much better efficiency, since the printer needs to wait for the tall parts to cool off before moving on to the next layer.

description.text:
this is a set of test bushing to figure out what size you should size your holes to make a 8mm brass self aligning bushing fit properly.
I designed it so someone else could tell me what size i should make the holes when i modify my x carriage for brass bushings. (i dont have any on hand)
the test bushings have the actual size printed on them.
UPDATE: 2/4/13 to clarify the marked size is the inside hole size.
I suspect that the porper size should be about 16.2mm  you can print the whole set as a plate or one at a time till you find the proper one.

comments.text: My general rule of thumb is: exact size hole if you want a screw to cut its own thread.  0.2mm extra for tight press fit, might require a hammer. 0.4mm for tight thumb fit, push in with a thumb but will stay put.  Double the tolerances for plastic on plastic.

just a heads up for people DL-ing the V1.2 case, it is designed to have the compiste jack removed for it to work
I now included a Start/Select buttons, these are made for tactical switches Update! V1.2
V1.2 is here! Changelog:
1.I found the case too tall, but I still wanted to keep the top retention, so i designed a clip to hopefully keep it in place.
2.D-pad stud bumped up 3mm
  • added "Adafruit's Pi-Boy Remixed" lettering, removed A/B(will return later, maybe) and made start/select lettering bigger.
  • added battery vents like the Original GameBoy
  • bumped the raspberry-pi's studs down .5mm.
  • closed up the direct power port and Ethernet cable port. for a more clean appearance
    • Like, share and feedback are appreciated! This is a remix of Adafruit's Pi-Boy. I liked the original design but found it lacking in certain areas.
    Improvements in V1.1:
  • increased top case lug size, doubling it to the point that you could friction weld it to side of the case if you find it lacking.
  • made the case taller to allow two more lugs to be used. helping the top of the case to stay together.
  • added the writing on the top of the case (YES I KNOW A AND B ARE BACKWARDS AS ARE START/SELECT. THIS IS MY PREFERENCE!)
  • Adjusted the height of the control lugs, I am using tactile switches instead of the SNES controller as i found it impossible to get the pads of the soft keys to line up. plus the tac switches have a better break point.
Follow Adafruit's instructions.

Print these and add a few components to have a fully working Delta 3d Printer.
You will need:
3 x Arms
1 x Base
1 x End Effector
1 x Top (MK1, MK2, or the new MK3 with internal wiring runs)
3 x Uprights
6 x Hangers
In addition to the printed parts you will need:
3 x Nema 17 geared steppers
1 x Nema 17 stepper
1 x control board
3 x endstops
1 x heated bed
1 x J Type hotend
1 x extruder (Tito is my favourite)
2 x push fit connectors
6 x 4mm carbon rods
12 x Traxxas rod ends
500mm Teflon tubing
various screws
Some wire

Create customized orthotic insoles using the makerbot customizer. These provide arch support, and are designed to spring a bit when you step. They may have variable thicknesses, and can be modified to fit each foot separately.
Note: Fixed a problem with the mesh; customizer should work properly now.

Measure your feet in millimeters and adjust accordingly. If your only measuring tape is in inches, you can convert by multiplying the number of inches by 25.4.
Customize these, print them out, and slip them under your shoe's insoles for solid, springy arch support. Typically, orthotic inserts such as these cost upwards of one hundred dollars. Per pair. With these customized inserts, you can print out a set that fits your feet, and create as many pairs as you need, nevermore having to switch out your inserts every time you switch shoes.
Print these out and try them. You won't want to go back!

This is a mounting bracket for the Scanguage.  The concept is based off using the rear view mirror as support. This allows you to place the Scanguage above or below the rear view mirror.  
I designed this to solve two problems.  The first one is if you mount the Scanguage on top of the dash you may get a reflection in the windshield, especially at night.  Also I found that the backlight was too much at night.  The second issue was that neither velcro nor command strips were able to keep this rather light device put. In both cases the device was coming off the fasten (velcro/command strips).

By moving the Scanguage next to the rear view mirror:
The Scanguage is still easily visible while diving
The backlight is no longer distracting at night
Scanguage is out of sight of thieves

This is a multipart design.  The first part attaches to the rear view mirror stem (the part that connects the rear view mirror to the windshield).  This consists of two halves that bolt together around the stem.  This serves as the connecting point to the mirror.  The second part connects to the Scanguage.  This version is design to use the screws in the back of the Scanguage as the attaching point. This is achieved by removing the screws from the back of the Scanguage and replacing them with longer screws that pass through the mounting bracket.  This keeps the Scanguage in place.  A bolt connects the two pieces together and allow adjustment of the angle to accommodate different mirrors, viewing angles, and mirror adjustments.  
Also included is an extension arm in case more distance between the two parts are needed.

This currently is designed for mirrors with round stems (the arm connecting the mirror to the windshield).  There are some manufactures that do not use round stems for their rear view mirrors.  As is this bracket will not work with those mirrors.

Included is the stl files (.stl) for printing. Also included is the 123D design files (.123dx) for those familiar with the free software from Autodesk and wish to tweak the design. Autodesk 123 Design is available at http://www.123dapp.com/design for Web, Windows, Mac, and iOS.

21 March 2014: Non-Substantive changes
2 Feb 2013: Initial Upload
3 Feb 2013: Added Scanguage II/Scanguage D bracket file.
11 May 2013: Added Scanguage-e version with screw holes

Your attention should be on the road and you should have an unobstructed driving environment. READ AND FOLLOW the warning on page 2 of the Scanguage Manual. (http://www.scangauge.com/wp-content/uploads/documentation/sge-1-0/SGE_UM_101.pdf). This includes mounting the device and cable in a way that will not block your view or your ability to operate your car. When Installing this, make sure your rear view mirror is PROPERLY ADJUSTED and you have an UNOBSTRUCTED VIEW. I cannot be held responsible for a lack of common sense.

The mirror bracket is based on a mirror stem diameter of 0.8", either a spacer (such as electrical tape) or adjustments to the design may be necessary for those with a different diameter mirror stem.  
The Scanguage-e bracket is sized based on actual measurements off my Scanguage-e.  These were very close to the dimensions listed on the Scanguage website.  For the Scanguage II/Scanguage D the bracket is sized based on the dimensions listed on the Scanguage website, I have not yet been able to confirm that it is 100% accurate.

This bracket has a number of rounded edges,  while this makes a nice looking product, it may also make things harder to print in some cases.  
The extension arm has holes to store the screws that come off your Scanguage.  However in the first print these holes were too small and did not print correctly.  You may want to adjust accordingly.

Beyond a 3d Printer and plastic for printing, the following is needed for installation: To attach the Scanguage-e to the bracket:
#4 Screws, 24 TPI, 3/4 inchÂ long (4X 24 3/4 inchÂ); Qty: 4
Avoid those design to be recessed. Something similar to a machine screw, without a point, is best. Scanguage II/Scanguage D users may need longer/different size screws then those listed. To bolt the mirror bracket onto the mirror stem:
1/8 Dia. Bolt, 2 inchesÂ Long; Qty: 2
Corresponding nuts; Qty: 2
Corresponding washers; Qty: 2
Locking bolts (those with nylon) or 2 locking washer are highly recommended. To connect the mirror bracket and Scanguage brackets:
1/4 Dia. Bolt, 1/2 inchÂ - 3/4 inchÂ Long; Qty: 1
Corresponding nut; Qty: 1
Corresponding washers; Qty: 2
Locking bolts (those with nylon) or a locking washer are highly recommended. If your also using the extension arm double the quantity of items #5, #6, & #7.

Step 1: Read the warning & design sections in the description before beginning.
Step 2: Print the necessary parts. There are currently five sets of files. The first three are the Device bracket (two for the Scanguage-e and one for the Scanguage II/Scanguage D). The fourth is the mirror bracket (which contains two separate parts). Both of these parts are necessary in order to complete the project. The fifth is an optional extension arm. Available if it is necessary or desired.
Step 3: Purchase the necessary hardware (see supplies required).
Step 4: Test fit the nuts and bolts on the pieces printed.

Currently only the ScanGuage-e version has holes. The ScanGuage-D/ScanGuage-II versions do not have the requisite holes to screw through to mount the Scanguage to the mounting bracket.  These instructions will walk you through the process of marking the placement and drilling the screw holes until I can update this with the proper screw holes.   
To mark the holes first create a template.  I did this by making a photocopy of back of the Scanguage with an All-In-One Printer.  Any photocopy will do as long it is not scaled down.  Check the size to see it is a 1:1 print. (no scaling). I then punched holes where the screws are on the copy.  From there I aligned the template onto the bracket, trying to be as straight as possible and ensuring their was clearance on the back for the cable to plug into.  With the template aligned mark the location of the screws using the holes made. An awl will work best for this, though a marker may work as well.  From there you want to drill out the holes just marked. You want to make the holes just big enough so you can screw the #4 screws through but not big enough that the screw head passes through.  
To attach your Scanguage to the bracket, place the Scanguage face down.  Remove the four screws on the back and save them in case your ever want to reverse the process. At this point the back can come off the Scanguage. Place the Scanguage bracket on top of the Scanguage. Align the holes on the Scanguage with those on the bracket.  Use the 4 #4 screws to screw through the bracket holes and through the holes on the Scanguage from which the screws just removed came from.  This now reattached the back of the Scanguage with the rest of it as well as screwing the Scanguage to the bracket.

To begin decide if you want your Scanguage above or below the mirror. Take the two halves of the mirror bracket and place them around the mirror stem. On one end there is a tab or arm, for a lack of better words, coming out of the bracket. This should be pointed down for under the mirror installs and up for above the mirror installs. You will be using the two 1/8inch daimater,Â 2 inch long bolts for this. It should go Bolt, washer, bracket (both parts), washer, nut. This bolt runs through the printed 1/8 inchÂ holes in the bracket parts. Tighten, though do not over tighten. Align the 1/4 inch hole on the mirror bracket with the 1/4 inch hole on the Scanguage bracket. Using the 1/4 inch bolt attach the two parts together. Make sure you put the Scanguage upside right. Also it should go bolt, washer, brackets (both), washer, nut. Tighten, again do not over tighten. You may need to adjust the mirror to accommodate the Scanguage or to work around. Make sure you readjust it so you have a clear view behind you before calling it done. Also you may need to adjust the Scanguage to your liking. This may require loosening then retightening the 1/8 inchÂ and/or 1/4 inchÂ bolts. MAKE SURE THAT YOU HAVE A CLEAR VIEW THOUGH THE REAR VIEW MIRROR AND THAT THE MIRROR IS PROPERLY ADJUSTED BEFORE DRIVING AFTER THE INSTALLATION. Once adjusted run the cable along the A Pillar (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pillar_(automobile)) and then the roof. Plug the cable into the Scanguage and OBDII ports. Ensure the cable is tucked away so as not to interfere with your view out of the windshield. Once everything is bolted, connected, and adjusted you have successfully completed the installation.

title: Printrbot Simple 1405 bottom cover piece
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Well, the Printrbot Simple 1405 model doesn't seem to come with any way to contain the wires inside, so I made a cover piece to do so for mine to make it a bit tidier and thought I'd share it. It's meant for the 1405 model but it may fit other models with slight tweaks I don't know.
You will need an upgraded X-axis to print this on a Simple, as it's just over 12cm long.

There's a flat head screwdriver hole to prise the piece off if you want to remove it easily, as it's meant to be a tight fit. As you can see from my picture I haven't used a heated bed so my piece warped. I recommend you print this using a heated bed to keep it perfectly flat.
It uses clips to pop into the wire feed-through and screw hole recesses.
I've included my original sketchup and the fixed STL files so if you want or need to modify it to fit yours, you can.
Hope it's useful to someone.

EDIT:
I have added an option for those people who don't have a large enough build area to print it all as one piece, and don't wish to upgrade to print larger pieces. Please download and print files "left", "right" and "middle", and then glue them together.
You will need an upgraded X-axis as it's just over 12cm long, larger than the Printrbot Simple can print without the upgrade.

EDIT:
I have added an option for those people who don't have a large enough build area to print it all as one piece, and don't wish to upgrade to print larger pieces. Please download and print files "left", "right" and "middle", and then glue them together.
Printed in PLA. I recommend a heated bed or yours will be warped like mine is as you can see from the photo. It works, but it's not ideal.

100% infill is recommended, as it's not a thick piece. You don't need to use any support material, but you may need to rotate it 180 degrees on the X-axis before printing in repetier or whatever software you use, so the flattest part is at the bottom. I recommend using slicer.
Uses very little plastic and only takes about 40minutes to print depending on your settings.

N.B. Not every 1405 model will be identical, it will depend on how well the pieces were laser cut and how well you put your kit together. In order to make this fit your model perfectly I recommend printing only 2 layers of the STL, then stopping your print. Compare this to the underside of your printrbot circuit board area and modify accordingly. Once all good, finish the print and install underneath.

remixed_from.title: Mk8 Spring loaded Drive Block Replicator 1 / Duplicator 4 / FlashForge / CTC

description.text:
I like to see the Gear of my Drive Block as with big Prints and higher Temperatures the heat of the Stepper can be quite enormous. This leads to more Material left in the Extruder Gear. To clean up a bit without disassembling and while Printing (also to flow Air into from a Can to cool down everything a bit) i modified the Lever accordingly.
It's quite robust though the Spring should be have anyways the right length to not to press too hard on the Stepper (gets extra heat and Material stucked). Also the Heat can leak away more easily.
Normally another Fan is pointed to the glued heatsink on the back end of the Stepper but with some Materials this has a bad impact.
This should keep things more controllable.
Added the Left Lever also.
Added V16 to possibly add an PTFE (Teflon) Tube 3mm x 2mm to prevent abrasion of the Lever and have a better guide of the Filament. The other Hole ist for an Adjustable Feature, i will add photos later.

description.text:
Who says a zombie can be useful and productive member of a civilized society? They're heads make great pin cushions.
Here is a doodle I drew at work the other day, and just felt like bringing it to like...er... umm... unlife?
Well anyway its a special gift for someone specials who's as likely to have a copy of a fashion magazine as they are a copy of a necronomicon. lol.
UPDATED 2-25-12: Corrected SkethUp Model and fixed several errors in stl file. It should be good to go now. Thanks.

• Print a copy of both the Pin Cushion Base and the Brain Cutting pattern. I used 2 shells and 15% infill. I also used exterior support to handle the overhang.
  • Next paint the Pin Cushion Base in a sufficiently zombie fashion, or just print it in in a nicly necrosed color.
  • Then cut our four pieces of pink fabric to make the brain. Use the Brain Cutting Pattern to do this. Mark the outside and the inside. Cut the outside and sew along the inside lines.
  • Sew the Brain together and stuff.
  • Color the brain in an exceptionally zombified fashion.
  • Glue in the brain into the Pin Cushion Base using hot glue.
  • Add a piece of felt for a nice tongue.
  • Add a few pins (Good thing its mostly dead or that might sting a little.)
    For more detailed instructions visit my instructible on this project. http://www.instructables.com/id/The-Zombie-Pin-Cushion/

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Couldn't find any holders for the moto g that fit my phone with it's case on it, and that fit my existing car phone holder so made this one. The connector seems to be a standard fitting on cheaper mobile phone car mounts/holders.
Please note: This fits my phone with it's common S-type 'gel' case on (pictured). You will need to scale it down slightly in your software package if you wish to just have it just fit the moto g (minus a case) properly, if that's what you're after.
Sketchup and STL files included in case you want to modify the file.
Printed in PLA with 100% infill for strength. You will need to print supports for it which are easily broken off upon completion.

author: Extrudo

title: Spool Holder for Printrbot Simple Metal
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
One of the first projects we made when we set up the Fab Lab. We scoured the internet for spool holders, but were generally unhappy with what we found. Many of them were very flimsy, difficult to print, or simply looked ugly. So, naturally, we designed our own!
We cut the chassis from both 6mm corrugated cardboard 5mm wood. We think the wood is much classier, but either will work. The axle was printed on the Printrbot and requires no support material or brim (just be mindful of the curling that may warp the axle).

Simply cut out the chassis parts using a laser cutter. Our tool of choice is the Epilog Mini (hence, the 12" x 24" canvas size). Then glue the parts together using wood glue and let the chassis set for about a day.
On the Printrbot, simply print the axle. No support material or brim necessary. Just make sure that the first few layers stick securely to the printer bed. If you're using painter's tape, it's best to try to get the print on a single strip of tape that's tightly wrapped around the bed.
Finally, assemble and go!

Font = write/Letters.dxf

It’s time for a better build surface. I’ve used the painters’ tape that we all can get at a hardware store. Both the Blue and Green colored tapes. And they have limits. Here are some of the limitations I see with the Blue Tape. It comes in a couple different surfaces finishes; both work about the same.
  • No matter how well you clean the build table the tape doesn’t adhere well. Meaning that the tape doesn’t provide enough adhesion to the build surface.
  • The larger the surface area of the part being printed the more material shrink is had. See pictures. This shrink lifts the tape right off the table and thus distorting the part.
  • If you don’t clean the top tape surface with Alcohol or Acetone you run the risk of the first printed layer to not stick. And if you do clean the tape then you run the risk of the parts adhering to the tape too much. See Pictures
  • Often you only get one run of parts before having to replace the Blue/Green Painters’ Tape. This uses up tape quickly and slows down printing from extra set-up.
    • So, I spent some time with a tape supplier (see below) and they are in the process of supplying me three alternatives to the Blue or Green Painters’ tape. I have received the first sample and have tested it. I must say this is superior to Painters Tape.
  • Has higher adhesive tack and adheres to the table great. Seems more resistant to heat.
  • New tape has little to no lift as material shrink occurs.
  • I’ve tested the tape with and without cleaning the top tape surface and material adheres every time. So far.
  • On the first test I was able to produce “six” runs of large surface area parts before I noticed any change in the surface of the tape and with no bubbling of the tape. And I’ve run with different color PLA and no change in performance. I’m in the middle of the second test and results so far are the same.
  • Note: I haven’t tested with small surface area parts yet. I suspect that with a light cleaning of the tape with Alcohol or Acetone it will perform great.
    • If you are interested, below you will find the P/N and contact info for the tape/supplier I used for this little experiment and I’ll post results on other tapes as I get them and if I find they are superior to the traditional Painters’ Tape. Tape: 3M 501 (aprox 3 inches wide). Can be cut to most any width you want. Can get this from any tape supplier that supplies 3M products. I’ve worked with RS Hughes several times in the past (Bay Area). But, I’m closer to Sacramento now so that division is helping me now. Other than enjoying the support RS Hughes provides, I have no business or financial ties to them. I make no money from you buying this tape from them or anyone else (darn). But really, I just want to improve the 3D printing experience for all. I’m working from a sample so don’t know pricing yet. But, with fewer tape replacements, more runs per application, little to no bubbling, easy removal of parts from the build table, great adhesion to the build table, great adhesion with the PLA to the tape it’s hard to beat. Contact Info:
    Mark Tanioka
    Inside Sales Manager
    R.S. Hughes Co., Inc.
    2405 Verna Court
    San Leandro, CA 94577
    O: 510.562.3348 |F: 510.562.4277
    | [email protected] | www.rshughes.com | Long Nguyen
    R.S. Hughes Co., Inc.
    8120-C Berry Avenue
    Sacramento, CA 95828
    Ph: 916-737-7484 | Fx: 916-737-7490
    www.rshughes.com
    Last notes:
    I supplied the two files shown in the pictures but not sure you would have a need for them. These parts are to protect/store Alum Molds. But, were perfect parts to test the new tape with resistance to material shrink. This post is more about finding build table alternatives to what is accepted now. Would like to see others post their solutions as well. I use a Replicator 2. Parts are around 3 inches square and about 1/2 inch tall. Bottom wall is about .040 inches thick. Tape seems to be same thickness (or close enough) to the painters’ tape because I didn’t bother re-leveling the build table and it worked right off the bat.
    /
    Update (10/8/12):
    With one tape application (3M 501) I was able to print the large sample part 8 times and I was able to print a simple ring (used for shipment of parts) with a small foot print over 80 times (so far). I printed the rings in groups of 10 at a time and in several colors. I did move rings to different table locations for each print session. And I cleaned the tape surface with Alcohol 3-4 times. I attached the ring to use as a print sample.
    /
    So for me, its clear; the 3M 501 tape is superior to painters tape. I would have had to replace painters tape 8-10 times to print the same number of parts. Hope this helps. Best, Reamo

Just print the two parts and sand the joining edges then super glue. I glued the mouthpiece on. Let me know if you discover any other tips but it is working great for me.

This is a derivative of the Keychain Pill Bottle that you can place an instrument reed into the cap, fill the bottle with water and screw the cap on (with reed) into the bottle. The idea is to help clean the reed and lightly soften the reed before playing. EDIT: Do not leave your reed in this bottle for more than 1-2 minutes (thanks bigluc). Here's a link to proper reed care. I might try to update the design to accommodate some of the ideas in this article. http://reedhelp.wordpress.com/tutorials/basiccare/

*Print with a 3D Printer on high quality settings for threads to fit together well.  
*Insert a clarinet reed into the slot in the cap  
*Fill the bottle with luke-warm water about half way  
*Thread cap onto bottle with reed still in place  
*Wait at least 5 minutes before removing reed and playing and no more than 1 hour for risk of warping the reed.

comments.text: For any single reed, you shouldn't leave it in for more than 5 minutes or you'll waterlog it.

This engine mount is for making your Hobbyking Bixler 2 into a twin engined one. It has the bolt pattern for a normal 28mm outrunner motor.

The motor is 3 degrees downward, which will result in the motor being 0.5 degrees down due to the positive angle of incidence of the wing. I recommend printing it with 100% infill as it will make it stronger and will only add 2 grams compared to 40% infill. Rotate the part 3 degrees on the X axis in Repetier for it to sit flat on the printer bed. Mount the motor and glue it to the wing with CA.

comments.text: I got this to print, but it was a struggle at first. Of course rotated it to print standing on the motor mount plate, but it wanted to print just a bit of the brim face, and then started printing other layers in air. Checked it in the layers view in Cura, and it showed the same thing. I had to move it on the bed and pivot the object (as if on the motor shaft), and then it printed fine.

comments.text:
@stustu242 @dorsch
... I agree, you can feed two ESC from the same battery. Please remember to remove the red (+5v) power supply lead from one of the two ESC's servo/control cables. Otherwise you have two regulators shorted and risk burning the ESC and/or the receiver.
comments.author: jhsandell

comments.text: You would need to ESCs but could use one battery with a Y harness to split the power so each ESC is connected. You would likely need a remote with enough channels to use two channels and a mix for throttle. You could look up how to do this online, depends on the radio. My guess is flight time would be a little shorter, but should not be too bad. Not positive since I have never built a two motor plane.
comments.author: dorsch

comments.text: It does reduce flight time a bit, yes. Although that depends a lot on how you fly as well. I have it set up with 1 channel per motor, with differential thrust mixed to the rudder channel. It can now do a flat spin while stationary, rotating aroung its own axis at crazy speeds. Here is an onboard video (not with these motor mounts, I designed these afterwards):
comments.author: dorsch

comments.text: This is really cool. Sorry to be a noob, but is it simple to wire up a second motor? I'm assuming you need two ESCs? or can you use just one, and one Lipo would be enough? I'm guessing dual motors would shorten the flight time a bit?
comments.author: stustu242

comments.text: As mentioned by dorsch and jhsandell, yes you would need two ESCs. Using 1 Lipo is no problem, just make sure it is capable of supplying the Amps needed for the 2 motors. It does reduce flight time a bit, but not dramatically. It also depends a lot on how you fly, with two motors at full power it uses quite a lot of watts, but can climb vertically.
comments.author: stustu242

title: FairyFountain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is meant to be a fountain, so the frog body has a canal to pass a tube connected to a water pump. The water pump I got has a different diameter , but I fixed that by pasting it with industrial glue.
There are some holes to fill with something to add weight to the body but this is optional.
The main file with the frog and fairy Ive already printed and works fine, some assembly and gluing is required.
I have not yet tested the wings file, but placed it here anyways in case someone wants toi try it out.
This is still a work in progress, so any advise or input is more than welcome.

Print the main file using supports no raft necessary, once printed assemble the fairy upper body onto the waist and legs and carefully stick the arms as well. It may be a good idea to sand the parts separatelly to avoid breaking the arms, also use exacto knife to cut off supports in the frogs mouth and canal.
When its all assembled I use a lighter to heat up the excto knife and fuse the parts together so the connections are no longer vissible, this is optional.
I have not tryied to pront the wings, so if anyone tries them out let me know how it went :)

author: wachong

description.text: Coaster using a moire pattern.

Open in customizer or openscad. Most interesting variables to tweak:
  • moire_count -- changes the density of curves; 10 is a sweet spot.
  • moire_join_angle -- changes where the curve changes direction; higher is closer to the edge.
    • Inspired by the "moore pattern" art piece (http://bea.st/sight/moorePattern/).

Adhere the two halves together.  One should be upside down from the other.  
Paint with a silver color.  Once dry, paint with black and wipe the paint off the high points for an aging effect.

MOVE ALONG NOTHING TO SEE HERE http://s2.photobucket.com/albums/y44/LinkReincarnate/?action=viewÂ¤t=video-2010-11-10-17-27-20.mp4 Derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4674
Thanks to Sublime for his original Pencil launcher design. This can be strapped to your arm to fire small projectiles or trigger aerosol cans. It is small enough to fit inside of a sleeve. I also remade the firing latch to require more force to trigger. It fires via pullstring. Ideally you would tie the string to a 3d printed ring to place on your finger for triggering. This would ensure that you had to move your hand out of the projectiles path in order to trigger the device. Ie if this is mounted on the bottom of your wrist you would have to pull you wrist back and away from the gun to shoot it ala spider-man. If it's mounted on top of your wrist you would drop your hand away from the gun to fire it.Always use the safety pin from the original pencil launcher to lock the launcher when not planning a shot. MRK 2 Barrel Features Glueless assembly and a reinforced trigger post. Thanks again to sublime for cleaning those latches up for me. MRK 2 Piston features an extended handle for better grip on the safety.
MRK 3 Piston features thicker arms for stronger rubber bands and better alignment.

Use a rubber band attached to the rectangular post next to the latch to keep the latch level. (Double it over or use two to make sure it is taut. Tie a string to the latch and route it behind the bottom post before stringing it out the front of the launcher. Use velcro straps in each of the flat holes in the bottom of the barrel to strap it to your arm. Pull the string to fire.
To use with aresol cans ( and manually operated spray bottles) resize until the inside diameter of the barrel is slightly larger than the diameter of your chosen can.(Silly string for web launchers, Pepper spray for nonlethal self defense, and Butane for a flamethrower.You could also launch paintballs or paintballs filled with mace. Hows that for a 3d printed arms race?) Don't forget to resize along the length of the gun to match the height of the can. You then need to create a plastic disk with a hole in the center that the small part of the aerosol nozzle will fit into. The diameter of the disk should match the diameter of the bottle. This disk will go inside of the barrel just behind the muzzle. I am not going to upload the ignition system to the flamethrower part for safety reasons. (If a kid is clever enough to finish building it they are probably clever enough not to get burned.) If you are able to get it working from there you should be able to make it easily. I'll be posting a video soon of a version I am printing that works with a manual spray bottle and everclear to create a real life hadouken. FIRE IS DANGEROUS DON'T PLAY WITH IT. ABS IS VERY FLAMMABLE AND YOU REALLY DON'T WANT A HUNK OF BURNING PLASTIC TIED TO YOUR ARM I AM NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR HOW YOU USE THIS DEVICE AND THE USE OF FIRE WITH THIS DEVICE IS NOT RECOMMENDED

title: Delta Robot v1 with four arms

description.text:
All my designs & progress available @ Marginally Clever
Video
Scale model of a 4 armed delta robot used in automated manufacturing. I'm looking for better ball joints. A universal joint that mates to M3 would be fantastic.
If you use one of my designs, please let me know! I'd love to see what you make with it and share with others who are interested.

Kit with all parts available at http://marginallyclever.com.
Acquire four sets of http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/733
Acquire four hobby servos. I used TowerPro SG5010.
Acquire an Arduino UNO or better.
Acquire a 9v1a power supply.
Acquire a small breadboard.
print one end effector, four bicep, and four mounting brackets.
CAUTION! Mounting brackets in the pictures are flipped on the X axis. The uploaded model has been corrected. Your robot should look like a mirror image of this one.
Assemble as in the photographs. Hot glue the servo horns onto the biceps.
Upload the code from the github project @ https://github.com/i-make-robots/Delta-Robot
after you change NUM_ARMS to 4.
Share your experience in our forums @ http://marginallyclever.com/forum/

thanks for sharing your project. Two years ago or so I also thought into that direction, but I didn't find advantages in it. Which advantages do you see?
My result was: Since the system is overdefined (it maps xyz into a four dimensional space) mechanical wear is inevitable if calibration and sizing of parts are not 100% precise. Moreover, any hanging servo will cause severe damage to the structure. A tripod is by far more stable and fault tolerant.

comments.text:
A little bit tricky to create the inlays in the software i use - Cinemac4D. I would imagine an application like Solidworks would be easier?
But my process to create the design with extruded elements (type, flag elements), is to position those pieces 'into' the design and use a 'Boolean' to cut them out of the main shape. Then use a copy of those shapes to create the inserts. You just need to allow a tolerance for the inserts to 'fit' into the cutouts. I normally, reduce dimensions by .2mm at full size to allow a nice snug fit between parts.
Hopefully that makes sense?

title: Action camera mount for RC Celica

description.text: 3D printable camera mount for Tamiya DF-03Ra Celica RC car. Tested with Liquid Image Ego action camera. Should fit also for GoPro.

I printed the mounting plate with Dimension SST1200es and it fit perfectly.
When attaching the plate on the car, first fix the front part of the body normally using the pin-clips and after that, lift the rear end of the body above the chassis pins and slide the mounting plate under the rear spoiler (note the U-groove on the mounting plate). Then lower down the body and mounting plate through the chassis pins and use the pin-clips to fix it. I have a video on Youtube http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=czicHhEoDKo

author: Dogodile

description.text:
For 50mm headphone unit. Diameter is about 51-52mm.
50%+ infill & 0.2mm layer height You can make it smaller to fit 40mm unit.
3D Printed Sax and Clarinet Reeds!

These are still to be tested, so if anyone gets a chance, post it in the comments. I've printed them successfully @0.08mm layers on my replicator, with PLA (ABS not yet attempted, though warping will likely occur). I also suggest increasing the number of shells to 10 or more, this will help hold the tip together, only 0.25mm thick.   
Update 23/2: The MK1 with a bit of material removal is providing a very large range (A2-Eb6 I think) on the baritone. Will determine the ideal model and upload soon. I've also uploaded a short demonstration of the sound (more of a sharp edgy sound, just showing the range).  
Update 6/4: I've uploaded a few new ones, along with an updated version of the Baritone. Included are the Soprano, Alto & Tenor reeds for saxophone, and normal and bass Clarinet reeds. As before, these haven't been tested properly yet, but i've increased the thickness to a standard 0.5mm so that you can sand them down a bit. Prints seem to work best with PLA, ABS will lift up too much and make a rough surface. PLA is also easier to sand down if needed. If you need higher resolution STL's, let me know.

comments.text: did some tweaking on the design for tenor with no sanding it out played the wooden reed  so gj
comments.author: mbsthegreat

comments.text: did multiple tests with the clarinet reed. ideal print looks like 0.13mm thickness
comments.author: TheMek27

comments.text: Printed it with PLA, HIPS, SBS, ABS. Still test them, can't say nothing certain. For my c-melody tenor the almost optimal proportions are: X=0.9; Y=1; Z=0.75; 10mm shell. I printed it with 0.1mm layer height. All reeds are supposed to be sanded and cut.
comments.author: jolang

comments.text: Wow... just printed the clarinet reed like an hour ago, and with a bit of sanding, it plays ridiculously well. Don't get me wrong though, it definitely does not replace a typical wooden reed, because the sound is not as crisp and low notes are hard to hit. But for a plastic clarinet reed, this thing really shines. I was able to play nearly any song I could play normally on a wooden reed, as long as it was mostly high notes. Maybe with a little more sanding, the lower pitches will come out better. I printed it at .08 mm layer height, 10 shell, and 100% infill.
comments.author: PerpetualPrinting

comments.text: I just printed a clarinet reed for testing, 0.8 Z scale, PLA,  0.2 mm layer height, 20% fill density, and the results... WOW, this is amazing, I can play the whole range with a pretty decent sound quality

comments.text: As with all of these reeds, some sanding is required to get the most out of them. Assuming that you have printed straight to the bed (no raft), i recommend that you sand from the top down until you get a better sound. Being plastic, it will be a different sound to what you are used to (but fun to play with). Generally it will be a much harsher sound, but you can tune it to your liking.

The tip of the reed needs to be thinner and more flexible than can be made with ABS or PLA. If you have access to a different type of printer, and use nylon or similar flexible material, you might be able to achieve the right stiffness value.

comments.author: O_Lampe

comments.text: I haven't tried printing with HIPS, but it will give a different sound (lower density vs PLA, decreased youngs modulus). Limonene is used to dissolve HIPS, so i don't know how well it will work with a thin structure such as a reed. Using a paint brush you can probably gently smooth the surface nicely without overdoing it.

comments.text:
Hello. Nice experiments you did. The buzzing tone when using bronze filament is in a way good news for me. Because it shows that it keeps the acoustics of bronze, even though it is not pure bronze. I will try to reed more about Saxophone reeds because I know only about Harmonium reeds which is very different. In Harmonium reeds there are many procedures to avoid these buzzing sound. Most related to the shape of the reed.
Other thing I thought is that filaments with metals with less resonance shall lower the buzzing but maybe reduce the range as well. Copper should be a little less buzzing or maybe you could try stell. My guess it that trying few differences in shape or sanding might be better.

comments.text:
Now that you mention it, increasing the density of the material may help. I've actually got some Bronze filament, only problem is that i'm using a Replicator Mini atm, so i can't print reeds with flat surfaces very easily.
So far i've only compared PLA with ABS and found PLA to be superior due to its greater stiffness. So far i've found the Bronze filament to be better suited to sanding than plain plastic, and slightly stronger. This should allow for better reducing of the reed thickness once printed. I think i'll try experimenting with one this week, let you know how it goes.

comments.text:
Well, I tried making a couple reeds for my Alto sax yesterday, results were less than stellar.
Printed anywhere from 6 to 8 shells. at 100% infill, layer heights ranging from .08 to .05
straight off the machine, none of them made a sound, with some sanding, they started to work, but the instrument was horribly out of tune, only about half the notes would sound correct, while others would result in squeaks or be transposed way too high.
I reworked the .STL, making the thickness and taper closer to that of a natural 2 1/2 reed, and it produced better results (sounded correct on the mouthpiece when installed on the mouthpiece, but as soon as the mouthpiece was set on the instrument, honking and out of tune. even with further sanding and tuning, I couldn't get any of them to sound right; I tried just sanding the bottom of the reed, changing the top profile, nothing worked.
I may try again today, I'll thoroughly map a natural reed's profile with a set of calipers, and try again to match the dimensions to what you've made, and try to get it to work.
They look right, but don't sound right. This is a bummer, since polymer reeds do exist, but are very expensive. If I could 3D print them, it would be very worthwhile.
I know some people have had success with the clarinet reeds,maybe I will look into how that was designed for comparison.
comments.author: Big-E

comments.text:
Thanks for letting me know how you're going with them :)
To date, i've only had multiple test runs on the baritone reeds, hence the 4 versions of it. Within a batch of ten, there can still be minor variations if the build platform isn't level, or bubbles form, so expect to trial a few if you think you are getting close.
The models i have uploaded are pretty close to No. 2 reeds in shape, though there is a fair chance that i got them wrong, not having tested afterwards.
You will probably need to reduce the thickness of the reed towards the base to get them working. To save on time, I am about to upload a new version of the alto reed for you to try out. I can probably re-model the remaining reeds as well, based on what i've learned with the baritone reed. It only takes a few minutes to modify them (when the model works the way it should - creo can either take a couple of minutes or hours, rarely anything in between), so i will give the rest a shot this weekend.

Max print dimensions 23 x 16 x 10mm Turn your old and unused USB wall charger into a night light! title: 92mm to 120mm PC Fan Adapter / Reducer Flush-Fit Wide-Mouth

description.text:
This is a 92 mm to 120 mm PC fan adapter specifically designed to allow fitment of larger 120mm fans onto 92mm mount surfaces, allowing for a cooler and/or quieter PC or project by allowing EVEN MORE airflow than the predecessor design via a box-shaped fitment that is much better suited to wide-open ventilation surfaces.
This .thing's design prevents much additional direct backpressure/backflow, allows for a wider spread of airflow, and doesn't leave gaps on the mount surface for air to escape. (For my use, it was created to upgrade an ASIC miner: GridSeed Blade, but it should work for anything else that uses 92mm fans)
Now you can use a quieter fan without sacrificing vital CFM!
..or upgrade to a fan with way more CFM!
Wow, Such Fan!.

Based off TheMeerkat's awesome selection of fan adapters (120to92mm)
Just print (with supports), prep parts, mount it up, plug in fan, and you should be cool.
If you're using this for a mining box like the Gridseed, it is advisable to move the ASIC so the fan overhangs an edge, or prop it up a little with a wedge or feet of some sort.

title: 40mm Fan Adapters Version 2 with Solidworks 2014 Source
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After 2 years (almost to the day which is ironic) I decided to revisit my fan adapters and I redid them from the ground up (knowing I was going to be including the source) to make it simpler for you to modify the source how you wished. I also thickened the walls slightly to help improve the print and I changed over to a revolved extrude and cut in case someone wishes to have even a thicker wall or make different angles etc...
What these do is convert a different sized fan (25mm thick) for use on a 40mm x 10mm fan connector. By doing this your noise level and sound level can be EXTREMELY decreased while putting out more CFM than a 40mm can ever do.
For the 120mm, 92mm, and the 80mm fan mounts there are extra tall versions (30mm taller) that allow more airflow to pass.
If you use the source you can adjust the throat length easily by editing the feature named "Throat Length Here". I did not make this an equation driven distance as that would have been overkill and it is just simpler for you to adjust it at the source for something this trivial.

This requires 3mm x 15mm fan mount screws for the 40mm side and 4.5mm x 30mm for the 120mm fan connection (4 of each type) and 4mm x 30mm for the others. All mounting fans need to be 25mm or adjust the length of the 4 screws for it. Use heavy infill for this since it will need it and I honestly suggest 50% to 75% due to the weight of the larger fans and the screws need the infill to really dig into.

comments.text: I printed the 120mm to 80mm extra tall and I have to say the tunnel wall is very thin ~1mm thick. With my PLA plastic the whole print wobbles when shaken. Not sure if the other models are like this but the thickness could and probably needs to be increased before this can be used. Also given the thickness of the mounting parts as well a M4 nut trap would be most excellent. Nevertheless these are great!

comments.text: I see no need of a nut trap and the 1mm thickness was fine but I did print it with 0.1mm height in PLA.  At 0.2 I am not sure how it would do and possibly would shake.  I tried making the (the source of these are included for anyone who has SW and is dirt easy to modify) walls 2mm thick but the air flow restriction went up but the major issue was the screw holes as the throat is as close as they can be without blocking the holes.
comments.author: JaredTS486

comments.text: Have you tested this for model cooling? Or better said do you think it makes sense to use a bigger fan for model cooling so you can run it slower and quieter?
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: This was made for a controller cooler but I will tell you model cooling is not what we are really after (causes all sorts of issues potentially) what we are after is a directed beam of cool/cold air at the filament as it leaves the nozzle.  I had a 120mm fan blowing on my parts and even PLA lifted on me but as soon as I removed that fan the lifting stopped.   Now if I could only find a way to do what the CNC mill/router people do where this flexible plastic hose points at the spot where the bit enters the material that is precisely what we need.  The problem is the back flow as it is absolutely hideous (even the 40mm adapters for cooling are horrible with it) so I am unsure how those mill/router machines do it.
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: It would indeed be awesome to have these hoses. How do we get the fans to pressurize the air better?
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

comments.text: "How do we get the fans to pressurize the air better?" Unknown to me and this is what I wish I knew what they used on those machines.
comments.author: Sungod3k

Got the real iPhone 6 finally and attacked it with some calipers. Made some quick cases and tried some prints on our Bukito Portable (deezmaker.com) and seems to work great. Not perfect but a good starting point.
The rest of the files are at:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/iphone-6-cases-negative-by-deezmaker
Also made a "negative" (with and without drafts) so you can bring it your fav 3D modeling program (like tinkercad.com) and subtract the iPhone 6 shape along with all the holes for the buttons. See pictures with the red & green parts.

comments.text: Sorry - I am going to have to second mkelly - perhaps you have an amazingly precise machine, but on a reprap prusa tightly calibrated, and using .3mm layer height this will not fit
comments.author: dlrion

comments.text: Did you have to sand down the case to get it in? Mine won't fit
comments.author: mkelly

comments.text: With our Bukito and Cura slicer, nothing was done to make it fit using pretty tight tolerances. What machine/slicer are you using? It is a little tight to get in, but flex the bottom corners a bit after inserting the top to get it in. It needs to be a little snug to make sure it won't come off : )
comments.author: mkelly

comments.text: Snug is one thing, but if you didn't add any tolerance over the stock size it won't fit properly. You need around .5mm on all ends to actually fit the phone. If you all you did was subtract the shape of the iphone then the case and iphone will try and take up the same space on all the overlaps and won't fit well.
comments.author: deezmaker

comments.text: Sometimes the filament's diameter precision can affect your tolerance quite a bit too. What machine and filament supplier are you using?
comments.author: mkelly

comments.text: We design 3D printers, so we do know a little about tolerances. Our machines may just be more precise than yours, but there is a slight gap of course (about .2mm roughly), but 0.5mm is way too much with our accuracy and it would have too much play.
